title: Risk management process
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 4.1 – “Risk management process”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document establishes, describes, and maintains an ongoing risk management process that:
- Covers the entire medical device life cycle (from concept through post-market).
- Includes risk analysis, risk evaluation, risk control, and production & post-production (P&PP) activities.
- Is integrated with or appropriately linked to the broader quality management system (QMS) / product realization processes.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A defined risk management PROCESS (procedure, section, or flowchart) that references ISO 14971 or clearly equivalent concepts.
- Explicit or implicit statement that the process applies across the device life cycle (not just design).
- Description of the main steps: risk analysis, risk evaluation, risk control, and P&PP activities (these may be named differently but conceptually should match).
- At least some indication of integration with other QMS processes (e.g., links to design controls, complaint handling, CAPA, PMS, etc.).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A dedicated “Risk Management Procedure” section that defines scope, key activities, and references related procedures.
- A flowchart showing risk management from pre-market through post-market with feedback loops.
- Statements like “This process applies to all phases of the product life cycle…” and “Risk management activities are integrated into design control, change control, and complaint handling processes.”

When to FLAG:
- The document references risk management in general terms, but it is unclear whether all life-cycle phases are covered OR the P&PP loop is vaguely described.
- It appears that risk analysis and control are defined, but their linkage to post-market monitoring is only implied, not clearly stated.

When to FAIL:
- No recognizable risk management process is described.
- The document only addresses a narrow subset (e.g., just risk analysis) without any indication that evaluation, control, or P&PP are part of a defined process.
- No link at all between risk management and other QMS/product realization processes.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- The process is described but not clearly mapped to life-cycle stages.
- Links to related SOPs (e.g., complaint handling, CAPA) exist but could be clearer.
- Missing or superficial flowcharts where they would improve understanding.

title: Management responsibilities (commitment, policy, review)
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 4.2 – “Management responsibilities”.

Objective:
Determine whether top management’s responsibilities for risk management are described, including:
- Demonstrated commitment (resources, authority, visibility).
- A documented risk acceptability policy.
- Periodic review of the suitability and effectiveness of the risk management process.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- Statements that top management is responsible for establishing and maintaining the risk management process.
- A documented “risk acceptability policy” or equivalent (criteria for acceptable risk and overall residual risk), approved or owned by management.
- Evidence that the risk management process is periodically reviewed for suitability and effectiveness (typically via management review or a specific risk management review).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A section assigning top-level responsibility (e.g., “Top Management shall ensure adequate resources, appoint a risk management responsible person, and approve the risk management policy”).
- A documented risk acceptability policy (in this document or by reference) that defines criteria and refers to applicable regulations/standards.
- Description of how management reviews the risk management process at planned intervals (inputs/outputs, actions).

When to FLAG:
- There is a general statement about management “commitment” or “approval” but no clear policy for risk acceptability and/or no description of how suitability is reviewed.
- Responsibility is mentioned in passing but it is not clear who owns the policy or review cycle.

When to FAIL:
- No mention of management’s role in providing resources, approving policy, or reviewing the process.
- No risk acceptability policy (or anything equivalent) can be found or inferred.
- The document suggests risk decisions are made without defined criteria or management involvement.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Roles and responsibilities could be clearer (e.g., no named role for risk-management oversight).
- The risk acceptability policy exists but is not clearly linked to specific device families or regulatory expectations.
- The management review of risk management is implied (e.g., part of general management review) but could be more explicitly described.

title: Competence of personnel
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 4.3 – “Competence of personnel”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires that people performing risk management tasks are competent and that their competence is maintained and documented (education, training, skills, experience).

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A requirement that personnel involved in risk management activities must have appropriate competence.
- Reference to training, qualifications, or experience criteria for those roles.
- Indication that records of competence (e.g., training records, CVs, competency matrices) are maintained, even if stored outside this document.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A section stating that risk management team members must have defined qualifications and that their training is documented.
- References to HR/training procedures or competency matrices that cover risk-management roles.
- Role descriptions (e.g., “Risk Management Lead,” “Clinical Safety Officer”) with competency expectations.

When to FLAG:
- The document mentions “trained personnel” but does not specify that this applies to risk management activities or lacks any pointer to how competence is defined or recorded.
- It is unclear whether competence is actually a requirement or simply assumed.

When to FAIL:
- No mention of competency requirements for personnel performing risk management tasks.
- No implication that training or qualification is needed for risk management activities.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Competency criteria exist but are generic (e.g., “adequately trained personnel”) without role-specific expectations.
- The document relies heavily on other SOPs for training without clearly linking risk-management roles to those processes.

title: Risk management plan (all sub-items a–h grouped)
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 4.4 – “Risk management plan”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document describes how risk management plans (RMPs) are created, maintained, and updated, covering all required elements:
- Device/product identification and life-cycle scope.
- Assigned responsibilities and authorities.
- Planned reviews of risk management activities.
- Risk acceptability criteria and method for evaluating overall residual risk.
- Planning of verification of risk control measures.
- Planning for collection and review of production & post-production information.
- Change control for the RMP itself.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A description of the RMP as a formal, documented plan (possibly per device/family).
- A defined STRUCTURE or TEMPLATE for the RMP that, taken together, addresses most of:
  - Device identification and life-cycle phases covered.
  - Named roles/responsibilities for risk-management activities.
  - Criteria for risk acceptability and method for overall residual risk evaluation (or reference to the risk acceptability policy).
  - Planning of reviews and verification of risk controls.
  - Approach to P&PP information flow back into risk management.
  - Version control / change history for the RMP.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A section “Risk Management Plan” describing required contents including scope, roles, review points, risk criteria, verification and P&PP plans, and change control.
- An RMP template attached or referenced that includes sections for responsibilities, risk acceptability criteria, verification plans, and P&PP information.

When to FLAG:
- An RMP is referenced, but only a few of the above elements are clearly defined and it is unclear whether the others are captured elsewhere.
- The plan is described only in very high-level terms, making it unclear if it would satisfy ISO 14971 expectations in practice.

When to FAIL:
- No risk management plan is mentioned or described.
- The document suggests risk activities are performed ad hoc without any planning document per device/family.
- Key elements (e.g., risk acceptability criteria, verification planning, or P&PP information flow) are completely absent from the plan or from surrounding text.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- RMP elements are scattered across multiple sections instead of clearly grouped.
- Change control for the RMP is minimal or only implied via generic document control.
- The method for overall residual risk is referenced but not clearly described.

title: Risk management file (RMF) & traceability
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 4.5 – “Risk management file”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document defines a risk management file (RMF) that provides traceability from:
- Each identified hazard/hazardous situation → risk analysis → risk evaluation → risk control measures → verification of implementation/effectiveness → residual risk evaluation.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A definition of the RMF as the logical collection of risk management records.
- An expectation of TRACEABILITY linking hazards through the entire risk-management process.
- Description of how the RMF is organized (e.g., index, traceability matrix, references to other documents/systems).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- An explicit requirement to maintain an RMF that “shall provide traceability from hazards to risk analyses, controls, verification, and residual risk decisions.”
- A description of a hazard log or traceability matrix structure.
- Indication that the RMF may point to other systems (e.g., electronic records) and is kept up to date.

When to FLAG:
- The RMF is mentioned, but it is unclear what it contains or whether traceability across all stages is required.
- Some elements (e.g., hazard list and evaluations) are clearly documented, but connections to verification or P&PP are not explicit.

When to FAIL:
- No risk management file concept is present.
- There is no expectation of traceability from hazards to controls and residual risk decisions.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- The RMF organization is described only at a high level; index or matrix is not clearly defined.
- Traceability exists but is limited (e.g., only hazard → control, with weak links to verification or P&PP).

title: Risk analysis process
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 5.1 – “Risk analysis process”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires conducting and recording risk analysis according to clauses 5.2–5.5, including:
- Clear scope and identification of the device/configurations.
- Performance of the sequence: intended use/misuse, characteristics related to safety, hazards/hazardous situations, and risk estimation.
- Recording of results with sufficient identifiers (device, date, analysts, etc.).

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A defined risk analysis activity or process that explicitly or implicitly includes 5.2–5.5 steps.
- Requirement to record risk analysis results and metadata (e.g., device ID, date, responsible individuals).
- Linkage of risk analysis records to the RMF.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A section “Risk Analysis” describing inputs, outputs, and required records (e.g., risk analysis report, FMEA, hazard analysis).
- Mention of using structured techniques (FMEA, FTA, PHA) with documented outputs.

When to FLAG:
- The document mentions risk analysis but does not clarify what is recorded or how the various steps fit together.
- Risk analysis is only referenced as “performed” without describing its main components.

When to FAIL:
- No risk analysis process is described.
- Risk analysis is mentioned only as a vague concept with no expectation of documentation or structure.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Risk analysis steps are present but not clearly aligned with 5.2–5.5.
- Metadata (e.g., analyst names) are not explicitly required but are implied by general record requirements.

title: Intended use and reasonably foreseeable misuse
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 5.2 – “Intended use and reasonably foreseeable misuse”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires:
- Documenting the intended use of the device (including indication, patient population, user type, environment, and operating principle).
- Identifying and documenting reasonably foreseeable misuse based on predictable human behavior, use errors, and field experience.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A requirement to document intended use and key contextual factors (indications, users, environments).
- A requirement to identify and document reasonably foreseeable misuse scenarios.
- Linkage of these definitions to subsequent risk analysis (e.g., hazard identification and risk estimation).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A section or template field for “Intended Use / Indications / Patient Population / User / Use Environment”.
- A specific requirement or section for “Reasonably Foreseeable Misuse” (or similarly named misuse/use error analysis).
- References to usability engineering or human-factors activities feeding misuse scenarios.

When to FLAG:
- Intended use is mentioned, but misuse is only vaguely acknowledged or not clearly required as an input to risk analysis.
- Misuse is only discussed in general HFE language without clear linkage to the risk analysis process.

When to FAIL:
- No requirement to document intended use OR the document treats intended use as implicit in labeling only.
- No mention of reasonably foreseeable misuse and no obvious way it would be captured.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Intended use is documented but lacks some dimensions (e.g., environment, user type).
- Misuse is identified but not systematically linked to human factors or post-market experience.

title: Characteristics related to safety
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 5.3 – “Characteristics related to safety”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires identifying and documenting device characteristics that relate to safety, including:
- Qualitative and quantitative characteristics.
- Limits/tolerances, essential performance, and other parameters that could influence safety.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A step or section requiring identification of “characteristics related to safety” (even if phrased differently).
- Expectation to document limits/tolerances or performance ranges that influence safety.
- Linkage between these characteristics and the subsequent hazard identification and risk estimation.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A risk analysis template containing a field for “Safety-related characteristics” or “Critical parameters”.
- Requirements to identify essential performance, alarms, control limits, and related specifications as risk inputs.

When to FLAG:
- Safety-related characteristics are implied (e.g., via engineering specifications) but not clearly required as a distinct step in risk analysis.
- It is unclear whether characterization is systematic or ad hoc.

When to FAIL:
- No mention of identifying characteristics related to safety.
- Risk analysis jumps directly to hazards without any characterization step of the device.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Characteristics are identified only indirectly through engineering documents, not clearly described in risk analysis controls.
- Quantitative limits are not consistently documented even though they are critical to safety.

title: Hazards and hazardous situations
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 5.4 – “Hazards and hazardous situations”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires systematically identifying:
- Known and foreseeable hazards.
- Hazardous situations (combinations of circumstances that could lead to harm) across the device life cycle.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- An activity or step to identify hazards (e.g., hazard analysis, hazard identification).
- An activity or step to define hazardous situations, not just a generic hazard list.
- Expectation of life-cycle coverage (e.g., normal use, maintenance, transport, disposal; interactions with other devices/users).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A hazard analysis table structure including hazard, sequence of events, hazardous situation, and potential harm.
- References to systematic methods (e.g., checklists, standards, prior device experience) to populate hazards/hazardous situations.

When to FLAG:
- Hazards are mentioned, but hazardous situations are not explicitly required or are ambiguously described.
- Life-cycle phases are mentioned but not clearly integrated into the hazard identification.

When to FAIL:
- No hazard identification step is described.
- The process assumes hazards are already known and does not plan for systematic identification.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Hazard lists exist but the concept of “hazardous situation” is not well explained.
- Life-cycle coverage is partial (e.g., strong on normal use but weak on manufacturing or decommissioning).

title: Risk estimation
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 5.5 – “Risk estimation”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires estimating risk(s) for each hazardous situation, including:
- Defining severity and probability scales.
- Describing how data, assumptions, and uncertainty are handled.
- Addressing cases where probability cannot reasonably be estimated.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A defined method for estimating risk (e.g., categorical scales, numerical estimation).
- Clear severity and probability definitions (or references to a policy/matrix).
- Instructions on what to do when probability cannot be estimated (e.g., treat as worst case, use qualitative approach, or specific policy).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A risk matrix or table defining severity levels and probability levels.
- Instructions for entering severity and probability per hazardous situation and deriving a risk score/category.
- Treatment of “unknown probability” aligned with the risk acceptability policy (e.g., considered high risk until proven otherwise).

When to FLAG:
- Risk estimation is referenced but severity/probability scales are not clearly defined.
- The approach to “unknown” or highly uncertain probability is not described.

When to FAIL:
- No method for risk estimation is defined.
- The process only qualitatively describes risks without any structured estimation or scale.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Scales exist but are not well justified or harmonized across product lines.
- Handling of uncertainty is implicit rather than explicit.

title: Risk evaluation
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 6 – “Risk evaluation”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires comparing estimated risks from 5.5 to defined criteria for risk acceptability and deciding:
- Whether risks are acceptable and can be treated as residual, or
- Whether risk control is required.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A clear link between risk estimates and risk acceptability criteria (policy or matrix).
- A decision step that classifies risks (e.g., acceptable, ALARP, unacceptable) and routes them accordingly.
- Documentation of evaluation outcomes for each hazardous situation.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A risk evaluation table with columns for risk score, acceptability category, and required action.
- Explicit rules like “Risks in the red zone require risk control measures” or “Risks below threshold X are acceptable.”

When to FLAG:
- Criteria are mentioned but not clearly applied (e.g., risk matrix exists but decision-making rules are vague).
- It is unclear whether all hazardous situations are evaluated or only some.

When to FAIL:
- No evaluation step exists; risk estimation is done but there is no comparison to any criteria.
- Risk decisions appear arbitrary or are left entirely to subjective judgment without reference to policy.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Criteria are defined but not well documented in this specific procedure.
- Evaluation outcomes are recorded but not clearly linked to subsequent risk control steps.

title: Risk control option analysis and documenting impracticability
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 7.1 – “Risk control option analysis”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires:
- Identifying and evaluating risk control options.
- Applying the priority order: (1) inherently safe design, (2) protective measures, (3) information for safety/training.
- Recording selected measures and justifying when further risk reduction is not practicable (and thus may require benefit–risk analysis).

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A requirement to consider risk control options in a structured manner.
- Explicit or clearly implied application of the priority order (even if not worded exactly like the standard).
- Expectation to record selected controls and rationale, including reasons why additional risk reduction is not practicable when residual risk remains.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A table where each hazard/hazardous situation has columns for inherent design changes, protective measures, and information for safety, with selection rationale.
- Text that states the priority and requires justification if the order is not followed or further reduction is impracticable.

When to FLAG:
- Controls are listed but there is no notion of “option analysis” or priority order.
- Impracticability is mentioned but not clearly tied to decision-making or benefit–risk analysis.

When to FAIL:
- No process for considering risk control options, only ad hoc controls.
- The document never addresses prioritization or justification of risk control strategies.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Priority order is implied but not clearly articulated.
- Documentation of impracticability is vaguely referenced (e.g., “per engineering judgment”) without clear expectations.

title: Implementation and verification of risk control measures (incl. effectiveness)
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 7.2 – “Implementation of risk control measures”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires:
- Implementing selected risk control measures.
- Verifying that they have been implemented as designed.
- Verifying their effectiveness in reducing risk (e.g., severity/probability).

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A requirement to implement selected controls via design outputs, process controls, labeling changes, etc.
- A requirement to verify implementation (e.g., design verification, process qualification, inspection).
- A requirement to verify effectiveness, i.e., confirm that the control actually reduces risk (often via validation, testing, or usability studies).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- Separate steps/records for “Implementation”, “Verification of implementation”, and “Verification of effectiveness”.
- References to specific test reports, validations, or clinical/usability evaluations as evidence of effectiveness.

When to FLAG:
- Implementation is required but verification/effectiveness is only implied.
- Verification is described but “effectiveness” is not clearly distinguished from mere existence.

When to FAIL:
- No requirement to verify implementation of risk control measures.
- No notion that effectiveness must be demonstrated; controls are assumed effective with no evidence.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Effectiveness verification is present only for certain types of controls (e.g., technical, but not information-for-safety).
- Links to verification/validation documentation are weak or inconsistent.

title: Residual risk evaluation (per hazardous situation)
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 7.3 – “Residual risk evaluation”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires, after implementing controls:
- Evaluating residual risk for each hazardous situation.
- Deciding whether residual risk is acceptable per the criteria.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A step to re-estimate or evaluate residual risk per hazardous situation.
- Application of the same or clearly related acceptability criteria used in clause 6.
- Documentation of the decision (acceptable/not acceptable, further action required).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A “residual risk” column in the risk table with evaluation outcomes and comments.
- Instructions that any residual risk that remains unacceptable must proceed to further risk control or benefit–risk analysis.

When to FLAG:
- Residual risk is mentioned but only at a high level (e.g., “Risks must be acceptable overall”) with no per-hazard evaluation.
- It is unclear how residual risk is documented.

When to FAIL:
- No per-hazard residual risk evaluation step is described.
- The process ends after risk control implementation with no follow-up evaluation.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Residual risk is evaluated qualitatively but not clearly tied to the numerical criteria used earlier.
- Documentation of residual risk decisions is sparse but present.

title: Benefit–risk analysis
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 7.4 – “Benefit–risk analysis”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires performing a benefit–risk analysis (BRA) when:
- Residual risk remains unacceptable despite all practicable risk control measures.
- The manufacturer wishes to justify acceptance of such risk based on benefit.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A trigger that when residual risk is not acceptable and further reduction is not practicable, a BRA must be performed.
- Expectation to use clinical/market data, literature, or expert judgment to compare benefits and residual risks.
- Requirement to document conclusions and decisions.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A defined BRA process with inputs (clinical evidence, literature, alternatives), method, and outputs.
- A requirement to record BRA conclusions in the RMF or risk management report.

When to FLAG:
- BRA is mentioned only in passing without clear triggers, inputs, or expected documentation.
- It is unclear who performs BRA or how it feeds into decision-making.

When to FAIL:
- No BRA concept or trigger exists; the process cannot handle unacceptable residual risks that cannot be further reduced.
- The document implies that all residual risks must be acceptable without considering benefit–risk.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- BRA exists but lacks detailed guidance on methods or data sources.
- Documentation expectations are minimal or not clearly linked to the RMF/RMR.

title: Risks arising from risk control measures
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 7.5 – “Risks arising from risk control measures”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires:
- Assessing whether implemented risk control measures introduce new hazards, hazardous situations, or modify existing risks.
- Feeding any new or changed risks back through the risk-management process.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A requirement to evaluate new risks or adverse effects introduced by risk controls.
- A mechanism to feed these new/changed risks back into hazard identification and risk evaluation.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A change impact assessment step that explicitly includes “risks introduced by controls”.
- A statement that any new hazards arising from controls must be added to the hazard analysis and evaluated.

When to FLAG:
- Change impact assessment exists but does not clearly mention new hazards or risks from controls.
- It is ambiguous whether newly created risks are systematically captured.

When to FAIL:
- No consideration of new risks arising from controls.
- The process implicitly assumes controls only reduce risk and can never create new risks.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- The concept of new risks is handled only under generic change control, not explicitly labelled as a risk-management requirement.

title: Completeness of risk control
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 7.6 – “Completeness of risk control”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires a review to confirm that:
- All planned risk control measures have been implemented and verified.
- Risk control activities are complete for all identified hazardous situations.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A final completeness check or review step for risk controls.
- Expectation to confirm that all planned controls are implemented, verified, and that resulting residual risks have been evaluated.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A checklist or review record specifically for completeness of risk control.
- A requirement to check that there are no “open” risk controls prior to final risk management review.

When to FLAG:
- Completeness is implied (e.g., “all actions must be closed”) but not clearly linked to risk control measures.
- The review step is present but it is unclear whether it covers all hazardous situations.

When to FAIL:
- No concept of a completeness check; risk control activities just “stop” without a final review.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Completeness review is limited (e.g., only design-stage controls, not production/post-production).
- The review is informal or lacks defined outputs.

title: Evaluation of overall residual risk and disclosure
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 8 – “Evaluation of overall residual risk”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires:
- Evaluating the overall residual risk of the device (considering all individual residual risks together) in relation to overall benefits.
- Deciding whether overall residual risk is acceptable.
- Ensuring that significant residual risks are disclosed to users in accompanying information (e.g., IFU, labeling).

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A defined step for overall residual risk evaluation (beyond per-hazard evaluation).
- Use of method/criteria for this evaluation (may reference policy or RMP).
- A requirement to identify and document significant residual risks for disclosure in labeling/IFU.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A dedicated “overall residual risk evaluation” section or report.
- Instructions to summarize major residual risks and confirm whether overall residual risk is acceptable.
- A requirement to include significant residual risks in the IFU/labeling.

When to FLAG:
- Overall residual risk is mentioned but no method or decision criteria are described.
- Disclosure of residual risks is present but not clearly linked to the risk management process.

When to FAIL:
- No concept of overall residual risk evaluation.
- No expectation to communicate significant residual risks to users.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Overall evaluation is qualitative and high-level but clearly present.
- Residual risk disclosures exist but are not systematically traced back to the RMF.

title: Risk management review & risk management report
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 9 – “Risk management review”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires a final review (often resulting in a Risk Management Report, RMR) that:
- Confirms the risk management plan has been implemented.
- Concludes on the acceptability of overall residual risk.
- Confirms that P&PP activities are in place.
- Is approved by a person/role with appropriate authority.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A formal risk management review step prior to commercial release (and/or updates).
- Expectation to generate a documented RMR (or equivalent).
- Requirements for content of this review (e.g., status of RMP, residual risk conclusions, conditions for release).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A section “Risk Management Review” that describes inputs, review activities, and the RMR as output.
- Requirement that the RMR be approved by top management or a designated authority.

When to FLAG:
- A general “review” is mentioned but it is unclear if it is specific to risk management or if it covers necessary conclusions.
- The existence of a report is implied but not clearly required.

When to FAIL:
- No risk management review is described.
- The process moves directly from risk control to market release with no final risk-management-specific review.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- RMR content is only loosely defined.
- The review process could better integrate post-market obligations or conditions of release.

title: System for production & post‑production monitoring
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 10.1 – “Production and post-production activities – General”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires establishing and maintaining a system to:
- Collect and monitor production and post-production information relevant to safety.
- Feed that information back into the risk management process.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A defined system or process for production and post-production monitoring (may align with PMS, complaint handling, vigilance, etc.).
- Clear reference to sources like complaints, service reports, nonconformities, market surveillance, literature, regulatory reports.
- Statement that this system is part of the risk-management feedback loop.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A “Post-Market Surveillance” or “Production & Post-Production Information” section tied directly to risk management.
- SOP references for complaint handling, vigilance, PMS plans, and trending.

When to FLAG:
- Post-market activities are described but their link to risk management is only implied.
- The system is very generic, leaving unclear whether it effectively supports risk management.

When to FAIL:
- No mention of production/post-production information relevant to safety.
- No mechanism for monitoring such information is described.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- The system exists but could be more clearly documented or integrated.
- Not all relevant information sources are enumerated, but core ones (e.g., complaints) are present.

title: Information collection (sources & mechanisms)
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 10.2 – “Information collection”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires collecting information from appropriate production and post-production sources, such as:
- Production records, nonconformances, and process deviations.
- Complaints, incident reports, service/repair records.
- Regulatory reports, literature, state-of-the-art and similar devices.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A list or description of information sources that are routinely collected and monitored for safety relevance.
- Mechanisms for collecting this information (e.g., databases, forms, periodic reviews).
- Linkage between collected data and risk management (e.g., feeding into hazard analysis, risk evaluation, or CAPA).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A table or section listing information sources and specifying who collects them and how often.
- References to central complaint databases, supplier quality data, service logs, and literature reviews.

When to FLAG:
- Some sources (e.g., complaints) are mentioned but it is unclear whether other important sources are considered.
- Collection is mentioned but mechanisms (frequency, responsibility) are vague.

When to FAIL:
- No defined process for collecting production or post-production safety information.
- Collection is purely reactive and not described as part of a systematic process.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Sources are generally defined but could be expanded (e.g., literature or “state of the art” not clearly included).
- Data collection frequency or trending methods are not well specified.

title: Information review & feedback into risk management
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 10.3 – “Information review”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires:
- Reviewing collected production and post-production information to determine its relevance to safety.
- Feeding relevant information back into earlier stages of the risk-management process (hazard identification, risk estimation, risk control, etc.).

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A defined review process for collected information (e.g., periodic safety meetings, safety review boards, signal review).
- Criteria or triggers for determining when information is safety-relevant.
- Expectation that new information leads to updates of the RMF (e.g., hazard list, risk estimates, controls).

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A “safety review board” or “PMS review” step with defined inputs and outputs.
- Instructions to update hazard analyses, risk evaluations, and RMPs based on review findings.

When to FLAG:
- Review is mentioned but not clearly tied to risk management (e.g., only a generic KPI review).
- It is unclear how often review occurs or how decisions are documented.

When to FAIL:
- No review mechanism is described for production/post-production information.
- Collected data are stored but not analyzed for safety implications.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Review exists but not all outputs (e.g., changes to risk controls, changes to labeling) are clearly defined.
- Criteria for escalation or re-analysis are vague.

title: Actions based on production & post‑production information
requirement_text:
You are evaluating ISO 14971:2019 clause 10.4 – “Actions”.

Objective:
Determine whether the document requires, when collected information is relevant to safety:
- Deciding whether action is needed (e.g., CAPA, field safety corrective actions, design changes, labeling updates).
- Implementing those actions.
- Updating the risk-management file and associated documents accordingly.

Core evidence to look for (minimal subset for PASS):
- A decision process for determining when safety‑relevant information triggers action.
- Examples or types of possible actions (e.g., risk assessment updates, design changes, process changes, field actions, safety notices).
- Expectation to update risk assessments, risk management plan/file, and other documentation when actions are taken.

Examples of strong PASS evidence:
- A flowchart from “safety-relevant signal detected” → “evaluation” → “decide on actions” → “implement and document” → “update RMF and related documents”.
- Explicit mention of CAPA, recalls/field safety corrective actions, and communication with regulators as part of potential actions.

When to FLAG:
- Actions are mentioned but it is unclear how they are triggered or how they link back to risk management.
- The document relies wholly on generic CAPA text without specifying the risk-management tie-in.

When to FAIL:
- No process for determining or implementing actions based on safety-related information.
- The system collects and reviews data but does nothing with it in terms of risk management.

Typical OFIs (can still PASS):
- Actions are described but updating the RMF/RMP is not explicitly mentioned.
- The set of example actions is incomplete (e.g., design changes mentioned but not field safety actions).
